A huge aspect of hummingbird flight, specifically their incredible stability, is a pocket of fluid in the back of their heads. Their flapping wings slosh that fluid back and forth, sort of offsetting that movement from being transferred to their heads; that's why you can see their heads being so insanely still, even though they are flying and moving. It's much more complicated and elegant than i've explained here, but if you're interested in hummingbird flight, how they keep their heads so still while in the air is something you'd probably want to know. And now you do!

I'm with the other commenters - please, please, please don't use the nectar formulas that contain red food coloring! It's not good for birds, not even good for children. It's much more cost effective to make your own nectar, just 1 part white sugar (never use raw or brown sugar!) and 4 parts water. Bring water to a boil, then remove from heat and add sugar. Storing the extra in the fridge is recommended, and clean the feeder thoroughly every time you refill, especially if you live in an area that has hot and humid summers. To clean the feeder, use hot water, a scrubber for the feeding ports, but don't use dish soap! Try diluted white vinegar mixed with water or 1:1 hydrogen peroxide and water. Rinse well and if possible let air dry before refilling and hanging. Make sure all ports on a hummingbird feeder are clean and free of dirt and such. In the mating season don't brush away all those cobwebs and spider webs around the house, and don't spray pesticides! Hummers eat small insects like some spiders, and use spider silk for their nests.

Destin,

I believe the "tail flick" you referred to occurs when the bird is quickly approaching the feeder. Imagine a bird coming in at constant velocity. Neglecting drag, the bird must direct the air straight downward, because the velocity is constant. But in order to stop at the feeder, it needs to provide a backward thrust. My theory is that the tail achieves this by redirecting the air-flow from the wings slightly forward, as well as adding drag to the bird to slow its approach.

Armchair physicist here. I've always assumed that like the tail of a conventional aircraft, the tail of a hummingbird is the distal control surface which primarily provides torque on the body of the hummingbird. Flicking the tail forward brings it into, or keeps it in the down-wash from the wings, maintaining control authority as it transfers from forward flight to a hover. It also generates a torque about the pitch access to counter the torque generated by the wings as they slow the bird.

There is a lot going on here that cannot be replicated by human experiments. The hummingbird swoops in and completes a series of complex moves simultaneously, just like a bird of prey attacking feet first. Dive at high speed, extend talons, increase drag, change center of mass. All of these happen smoothly, and in a way we cannot yet replicate.

The hummingbird is changing its center of mass, increasing drag (or acceleration in the opposite direction,) and making minor adjustments. All together.

I think the hummingbird does the tail flick to reduce his forward momentum. It's kind of like when we are running fast and need to stop quickly. I center of gravity at top speed is above and in from of our hips and we are leaning slightly forward. When we stop quickly, our legs go forward and we lean back a little and our center of gravity shifts, I'm not sure but I would think it would be somewhere in our legs. In forward momentum the center of gravity is forward. SEE COMMENT

@hassoun6 
It's spelled "Schlieren", German for streak.  The problem with Schlieren is that you can't visualize a particular cross section of the flowfield, you can only get the total flow disturbance, with total depth of the area of interest.  To quantify the vorticity you need to measure the 2D flow field orthogonal to the wing.  Long story short, Schlieren doesn't do this.  Read up on PIV and you'll see what I mean.
Learn about Shlieren photography. Save yourself some olive oil.
